div.head:
Embleme 27. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Hee that weeweendeavours to enter into the Philosophers Rosary without
a key, is like him that would weewewalke without feet.

lg.l: Roses in wisedom'swisdom's garden weewedoe abound,
But weeweallwayes under locks and bolts is found:
One weeweonely key it weewehath, of means weeweesteeme,
Yet without that you swim against the streamestream.
He, that can scarce upon a levelllevel stand,
In vainevain attempts Parnassus to ascend.

div.head: Discourse 27.
div.ab:
Concerning Erichthonius they write, that weewehee sprung from the seed of Vulcan-
cast upon the earth striving with Pallas the weeweGoddesse of weewewisedome, with ser
pentine and without weewehumane feet. Very like him are those, who, depending upon
the means of Vulcan alone, without the weewewisedome of Pallas, weewedoe begettbeget monstrous
children, namely, without feet and abortive, which can neither weewesustaine-
themselves, nor profit others: It is a miserable thing for a man to weewegoe on all
fourefour, that is, hands and feet together, but much more miserable to be weeweall
together destitute of feet, and to use armesarms instead thereof: for they seem to
have degenerated to the nature of weewewormes, who weewegoe after the manner of crea
pingcreeping weewewormes: But the two weeweleggs are the weeweorganicke parts in man, without which
hee cannot weewetruely weewewalke, as neither see without eyes, or touch things tangible
without hands: soeso likewise Medicine and every operative art is supposdsupposed to
have two weeweleggs, whereon to stand, namely experience and reason, without-
either of which that art is lame, and imperfect in its traditions and præ
ceptsprecepts, nor correspondent to the proposed end: weeweChymistry indeed weewecheifely de
lights in two subjects (as weeweleggs) whereof one is the key, the other the string of
the barrebar; by these the weewePhilosophicall Rosary lockdlocked on all sides is opened,-
and passage admitted into it to those that have right to enter: But if one
be wanting to him that is about to enter herein it will be the same thing, as
for a man whose feet are bound to weeweendeavour to outrunneoutrun a hare: weewehee that
enters into the garden, which is every way enclosed or fenced, without a Key,
imitates a theifethief, who coming in a weewedarke night can discernediscern nothing that-
growes in the garden, nor enjoy the things stolen away: But the key is a thing
of very little weeweesteeme or value, which is properly called a stone weeweknowne in the
chapters, and is the root of Rhodes, without which a twig is not put forth, nor-
doth the bud swell, nor the Rose become green, or discover multitude of-
leaves: But a weewequæstion might be weeweaskd, where must this key be sought for?
I anwser with the oracle, that is must be there investigated, where the-
bones of Orestes are weewesayd to be found, namely, where winds, the Striker, that
which is beaten weewebacke, and the destruction of men are found together, that is,
as Lychas weewehath interpreted it, in the Brasiers Shop or workehouseworkhouse: For the oracle
would have bellowesbellows understood by winds; a hammer by the striker an anvileanvil
by that which is beaten weewebacke; by the destruction of men iron: if a man weeweknowes
how to number well and distinguish the signs, weewehee will certainly find this key
in the northernenorthern hemisphere of the ZodiackeZodiac, and the string of the weewebarre in
the SoutherneSouthern: Which having weeweobtaind, it will be easy to open the weewedoore and enter:
and in the very entrance weewehee will see Venus with her Paramour Adonis: for weeweshee
hath tinged the white roses of a purple weewecolour with her blood: In the same place
allso a dragon is observed, as in the Hesperian gardens, which watched to weewepræ
serve the roses: The scent of the roses is weewesayd to be increased by garlickegarlic-
planted near, and that by reason of an excedingexceeding degree of heat, which appears
in garlickegarlic, in which respect it is a remedy against cold weewepoysons: for Roses-
Discourse 27.
require the heat of the weeweSunne and earth, before they can weeweattaine to weewecolour and
scent most weewegratefull to the eyes and nose: Moreover the fume of weewecomon Sulphur
makes red roses white, where it touchethtouches, on the contrary the spirit of VitriollVitriol
or Aqua fortis restores them to a deep red weewecolour, which endurethendures: For weewecomon-
Sulphur is an enemy to the weewePhilosophicall Sulphur, though it cannot destroy it,
but the Solutive water is weewefreindly, and weewepræserves its weewecolour: The rose is conse
crated to Venus in regard of beauty, in which it surpassethsurpasses all other flowers:-
for it is a Virgin, which nature weewehath armed, that it might not be violated with
out revenge and punnishmentpunishment: Violets are weewevoyd of weapons, and trodden under
foot; Roses being comprised within prickles have yellow weewehaire inwardly; and
outwardly a green garment: weeweNoe man can pluckepluck, and separate them from-
the prickles but weewehee that is wife, if otherwise, weewehee will weewefeele a sting in his-
fingers: SoeSo none but a most wary Philosopher will pluckepluck the flowers, ex
cept weewehee would find bees and stings in the hives, and gull with honey. Many-
men have secretly and feloniously entredentered into the Rosary, but reaped nothing-
from weewetheme but misery; that is, lost their weewelabour. Hereupon weeweSayth Bacusser in-
Turba; Our weewebookes weeweseeme to be very injurious to those, who read our writings
onely once, twice, or thrice, whereas being frustrated in their understanding and-
they have spend any in this art. And a little after, For when a man thinks weewehee
hath done, weewehath the world, weewehee will find nothing his hands. . . . .
